newsitem.title: USA: Apple rehires its old ad agency, TBWA Chiat/Day.
newsitem.headline: Apple rehires its old ad agency, TBWA Chiat/Day.

text.p: Apple Computer Inc. confirmed Friday that it was reuniting with TBWA Chiat/Day, the advertising agency that created the highly acclaimed television commercial that launched the Macintosh personal computer in 1984.

Troubled Apple, which this week announced a stunning series of actions to turn itself around, said it selected TBWA Chiat/Day, a unit of Omnicom Group, to handle its U.S. advertising. The move would not immediately affect Apple's international advertising.
The size of the account was not disclosed, but trade publications put it in the $80 million to $90 million range.
Apple officials said it was too early to know what specific advertising messages will emerge but said marketing will focus on the company's traditional strengths in creative content and education.

"We've tried to compete in too broad a space," David Roman, vice president of advertising and brand communications, said in a telephone interview. "If we really focus on areas where we are unique, Apple is a driver in many spaces in the marketplace."
He cited graphics, publishing, design, multimedia authoring and Web authoring as the creative areas that would be highlighted in Apple's marketing.
Roman said the effort would also include expanding Apple's brand name.
"We have one of the few brand names in the industry," he said. "The issue is making it more relevant to where computing is going today."

Apple, which has seen its earnings and market share plummet in recent years, announced Wednesday that Microsoft Corp., its bitter arch-rival, was investing $150 million in the company and that Apple's board of directors was being revamped.
TBWA Chiat/Day is the successor to Chiat/Day, the agency that created the well-known "1984" commercial that launched the Macintosh PC.
The television spot, shown during the Super Bowl, portrayed a hammer-wielding woman athlete attacking a giant Orwellian video screen representing numbing conformity.
Apple began its review of advertising agencies in June. Its agency for U.S. advertising, BBDO Worldwide, declined to participate.
Apple's stock, which surged after Wednesday's announcements, lost $2.38 to $26.81 Friday on the Nasdaq market, where it was the third most-active issue.
